The Earth revolves around the Sun in an elliptical orbit.
Water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit or 0 degrees Celsius.
The speed of light in a vacuum is 299,792,458 meters per second.
The human body is composed of trillions of cells.
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert carbon dioxide into oxygen.
The periodic table organizes chemical elements based on their properties.
Gravity is the force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.
The square root of 25 is 5, which is an irrational number.
DNA is the hereditary material found in cells of living organisms.
The Earth's atmosphere is primarily composed of nitrogen and oxygen.
Electromagnetism is one of the four fundamental forces in nature.
The sum of the angles in a triangle is 180 degrees.
Gold is a dense, soft, shiny metal with the atomic number 79.
The Sahara Desert is the world's largest hot desert.
Mitochondria are the powerhouses of cells, generating energy through respiration.
The Pythagorean theorem relates the sides of a right triangle.
The Milky Way is the galaxy that contains our Solar System.
Atoms are the basic units of matter, composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Water expands when it freezes, which is an anomalous property.
The human body is made up of multiple organ systems.
The speed of sound in air is about 343 meters per second.
Glucose is the primary source of energy for cells.
The Nile River is the longest river in the world.
Photons are the elementary particles that make up light.
Plate tectonics explains the movement of the Earth's lithospheric plates.
The Fibonacci sequence is a series of numbers where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones.
The human heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles.
The color of an object depends on the wavelengths of light it reflects.
The boiling point of water at sea level is 212 degrees Fahrenheit or 100 degrees Celsius.
The Earth's magnetic field is generated by its molten outer core.
Precipitation can occur in the form of rain, snow, sleet, or hail.
The Periodic Law states that the chemical properties of elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers.
The density of an object is its mass divided by its volume.
The International Space Station orbits the Earth at an altitude of about 400 kilometers.
Diffusion is the movement of particles from an area of high concentration to low concentration.
The Cartesian coordinate system uses x, y, and z axes to locate points in space.
Combustion is a chemical reaction that releases energy in the form of heat and light.
The Earth's rotation causes day and night cycles, as well as the apparent movement of celestial bodies.
The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be transformed.
The human body requires essential nutrients like vitamins, minerals, proteins, carbohydrates, and fats.
The wavelength of visible light ranges from approximately 400 to 700 nanometers.
The force of friction opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact.
The Richter scale is used to measure the magnitude of earthquakes.
The Doppler effect explains the change in frequency of waves due to relative motion.
The Krebs cycle is a series of chemical reactions in cellular respiration.
The Archimedes Principle states that the buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the displaced fluid.
Osmosis is the movement of water molecules across a semipermeable membrane from a region of high concentration to low concentration.
The speed of an object is the rate of change of its position over time.
Thermodynamics is the study of the relationships between heat, work, temperature, and energy.
The human genome is composed of approximately 3 billion base pairs of DNA.
The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 meters per second squared.
The greenhouse effect is the process by which certain gases trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere.
The atomic number of an element is equal to the number of protons in its nucleus.
The law of conservation of mass states that mass cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction.
The surface area of a sphere is equal to 4π times the square of its radius.
The Second Law of Thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system always increases over time.
The wavelength of a wave is the distance between two consecutive crests or troughs.
The Bernoulli's Principle explains the relationship between fluid flow and pressure.
The International System of Units (SI) is the modern form of the metric system.
The human body maintains a constant internal temperature of approximately 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (37 degrees Celsius).
The Avogadro's constant is the number of particles in one mole of a substance.
The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that the more precisely the position of a particle is measured, the less precisely its momentum can be known.
The Pauli Exclusion Principle states that no two fermions can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously.
The Hubble's Law describes the relationship between the recessional velocity of a galaxy and its distance from the observer.
The valence electrons of an atom determine its chemical properties and behavior.
The Law of Definite Proportions states that a chemical compound always contains the same proportion of elements by mass.
The Ideal Gas Law relates the pressure, volume, amount of substance, and absolute temperature of an ideal gas.
The charge of an electron is approximately -1.602 x 10^-19 coulombs.
The half-life is the time required for half of the atoms in a radioactive sample to decay.
The mass of an object is a measure of its resistance to changes in motion.
The alkali metals are the most reactive group of elements on the periodic table.
The Coriolis effect describes the deflection of objects due to the Earth's rotation.
The Schrodinger equation is a fundamental equation in quantum mechanics that describes the behavior of particles.
The Law of Reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.
The momentum of an object is equal to its mass multiplied by its velocity.
The Stefan-Boltzmann law describes the power radiated from a black body in terms of its temperature.
The Clausius-Clapeyron equation relates the vapor pressure of a substance to its temperature.
The Kelvin scale is an absolute temperature scale where zero degrees Kelvin is the coldest possible temperature.
The Hubble Space Telescope is a space observatory that orbits the Earth and captures high-resolution images of celestial objects.
The Second Law of Motion states that the acceleration of an object is proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
The surface area of a cube is equal to six times the square of its edge length.
The volume of a cylinder is equal to π times the square of its radius multiplied by its height.
The atomic mass of an element is the average mass of its naturally occurring isotopes.
The Boyle's Law states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature.
The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
The Kepler's Laws describe the motion of planets around the Sun in elliptical orbits.
The Faraday's Laws of Electrolysis relate the mass of a substance produced during electrolysis to the quantity of electricity transferred.
The Planck's constant is a fundamental physical constant that relates the energy of a photon to its frequency.
The principle of conservation of angular momentum states that the total angular momentum of a closed system remains constant.
The law of conservation of linear momentum states that the total linear momentum of an isolated system remains constant.
The chemical formula for water is H2O, consisting of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.
The wavelength of visible light is inversely proportional to its frequency, according to the wave-particle duality.
The Earth rotates on its axis once every 23 hours, 56 minutes.
The mass of the Sun is about 330,000 times greater than Earth's mass.
The chemical symbol for water is H2O, composed of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second.
The force of gravity is an attractive force between objects with mass.
The Periodic Table of Elements arranges elements based on their atomic number and electronic configuration.
The human body is composed of numerous organ systems, including the cardiovascular, respiratory, and digestive systems.
The boiling point of water at standard atmospheric pressure is 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit).
